messages.message: @Piyush investigating — thanks for bringing to our attention.

Hi @Piyush, the multipart file upload operation in `openapi.yaml` falls under Anil’s team’s scope. It was originally tracked in FLOW-10112 (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/FLOW-10112) and moved to EPD-4670 (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-4670). @Anil would be the best person to provide a status update on that ticket. Meanwhile, we do have documentation on how to use multipart upload at https://docs.instabase.com/api-sdk/multipart-upload, though I know that’s not exactly what SocGen needs.

@jean FYI
My understanding is that Andy Wang was in charge of this, but once he left it was hard to find resources for it. But Anil can confirm if that’s right.

@Anil thats correct. Its in the docs (https://docs.instabase.com/api-sdk/multipart-upload) but missing in the yaml. Since the client team is heavily relying on the docs for dev, we are facing a lot of questions from them on this topic.
@Chris Cowell although i understand it maybe another team, i am looking for a way to make sure that our docs allow customers to self serve

@Piyush I understand both your and the customer’s frustration, and we want to help however we can.

To make the docs process completely transparent: the API docs are autogenerated from the `openapi.yaml` spec. We supplement those autogenerated pages by hand-writing docs for API operations that aren’t yet included in `openapi.yaml`. A great example of that is the hand-written docs page you mention above, which describes how to use multipart uploads.

Once EPD-4670 is done, the spec for the multipart upload operation will be in `openapi.yaml`, and new API documentation for that operation will be auto-generated from that spec. At that point we can delete the hand-written page for multipart uploads.

It sounds like SocGen is relying on `openapi.yaml` entirely, and not referring to the hand-written docs page? Using that page should allow them to self-serve for this operation, until EPD-4670 adds the operation to `openapi.yaml`. But is there some problem with that strategy, that we can help with?
